This game is tons of fun. For an early access, it already has an incredible amount of polish. The game currently gives access to a handful of campaign missions, which give access to more types of missions and eventually cosmetic options.

There are a total of 9 main missions. They are structured in a roguelike format, you basically start with nothing (other than ship upgrades and stuff on your character) and progress along mission nodes that you can choose from. Loot mainly comes from completing the mission objective in those nodes, such as ship parts, credits are weapons. These vary from clearing an enemy outpost, stopping a jammer that's keeping you from jumping to the next node and such. Not much variety but still a good time. Mission and structural layouts are quite same-y, but it's not a big deal for now and the devs seem to be updating to keep the game fresh (Recently they added a vendor update and mutation modifiers to missions). At the end you complete the main mission and once that's done you can return to the hub. Wishing the devs luck for the future

Gameplay wise, everything feels solid. The weapon variety is currently lacking, only boasting a handful of weapons, that can range from mk0 to mk3 variants, which can either be purchased from the starting hub with credits, or found inside missions as random spawn or loot. The moment to moment gameplay however is very satisfying and barely any jank. Most importantly they have an unstuck button which so many EA games seem to avoid for some reason, which comes in handy sometimes when you get into weird out of bounds issues, but those aren't frequent.

The flight mechanics are nothing fancy, but as everything else fluid and smooth to control. You can pilot the ship, shoot out from tubes into space, repair ship core using kits, recharge shields (manually I might add, by crafting a shield kit, then going on the bridge outside and interacting with the shielding interfaces), maintain the ship (putting out fires, repairing faulty equipment and more). This all sounds like a lot, however once you get more familiar it feels very smooth going. If you've played Warframe's space combat, it's pretty much like that.

There is currently only server browsers for multiplayer purpose. I've mostly done solo, which has been a great experience too, you get a robot buddy (named buddy) who helps you out in ship combat as well as ground combat. He is VERY competent as an NPC which is refreshing. The multiplayer part of the game is also quite fun. However currently there seems to be some performance issues which hopefully will be addressed as time goes on.

Currently the game released with only chapter 1, and the story isn't all that grand, but intriguing enough to keep me wondering what the future holds for this game. The NPCs are all voice acted, and each of them are top tier and radiates personality. I hope they extend these interactions more in the future. I specially like the mad scientist guy named Vosk who basically sounds like Emperor Palpatine. 

The game is looking very solid and I hope the devs keep on delivering with new content and story elements. Wishing them all the best and hope the community for this game grows

Another case where I wish there was a 'mixed' option.

I wanna make this clear, the game feels great to play. For a few hours, me and my friend had tonnes of fun. There's not much content, and what's there gets repetitive, but that's the nature of early access: it's a great starting point and I'm very happy to see what comes in the future. I really want this game to succeed, which is why I'm gonna go into a lot of detail on my thoughts for the improvements (this 'review' will be *very* long and is more for the devs than other potential players). I want to make clear I'm not going to be critical out of hate, but more out of love and out of foresight for how incredible this game could be if it gets things right.

There are a few niggles I think would really help the feel along, like inertia when moving through 0G (currently the ship controls are weird, and I think them being too responsive is to blame for that, also if you let go of movement keys both in ship and on foot in 0G, you just come to a stop very quickly which feels weird, unnatural and I would much prefer if you kept your momentum). This could be implemented in such a way as 'Space Engineers', where you have dampers you can turn on and off, which when on allow you to slowly come to a stop when you are not inputting movement, and would have the 'Jet Drive' slow down before stopping instead of just coming to an almost instant stop. The is would help emphasise the 'space' feel of the game, which currently feels more cosmetic than mechanically impactful. 

I also feel an air-dash would take the on-foot combat to the next level - it already feels pretty Doom-like (fast paced, close quarters combat feels very fun) and honing in on that aspect and developing it further would elevate an already fun combat system to be the 'star of the show'. You have a double jump, so an Air-Dash wouldn't break the established 'rules' - you'd be using the same propulsion that enables the double jump (which would assumedly be the dampers), just directing it to move the player in whatever direction the player is inputting instead of upwards. Could even have them be restricted by the same 'cool down', so can either do a double jump *or* an air dash. That would also emphasise that they use the same propulsion system and add a bit more connection between the setting and the mechanics.

In tune with these movement modifications, having some content that requires entry into, say, abandoned satellites that don't have active gravity, making the player explore it and do combat, objectives, etc in 0G. Maybe these places already exist, but in the time it took us to hit Lv 5, we didn't encounter any objective that wasn't either 'use the ship' or 'have some artificial gravity'. Maybe can scatter some sparse 'anchor points' that people can grapple to in these areas that can help with people who might get a little motion sick or head-spinney from 0G combat, so those players have an option to fight with boots on the ground, but the sparsity would encourage the 0G combat, and if they wanted to fight on a surface, they would need to search for an anchor point whist under fire from the enemy, adding some agency and active decision making during these combat encounters.

I would very much recommend being able to adjust the difficulty of combat though (ship combat and on-foot combat should be adjustable separately), because as it stands it's very easy. Even just a simple 'player takes x% more damage' would do wonders. Don't necessarily make enemies tankier though, that doesn't fix the problem - the direction I'm coming from is the view that enemies should die quickly, but so should the player - emphasising risk vs rewards, especially in group combat as you would need to actively pay attention to the enemy types and fight around which ones are currently appearing. As it stands, if one of those 'explode-y drones' flies at me in combat, I know I can easily dodge it, so I don't need to pay attention to them, but what makes it worse is that even if I don't dodge it... It just breaks my shield and does 10 damage. Which is just pathetic. It's a completely ignorable enemy, just like the 'spider drones' (which have no range and I'm not sure I've ever been hurt by one, I hardly tend to notice they're there), and any enemy that's outside of shotgun range because they basically can't hit (nor kill) you unless you deliberately stand still. Again, in our time getting to Lv 5, neither me nor my friend ever died, except one time where my friend fell into a 'death pit' because he wasn't paying attention. Recharging shield is fine, that's not the problem, neither is the accuracy of the enemies (although I would increase the average accuracy, and also make it scale with the number of enemies shooting at the player, so more enemies means a bit less accuracy and/or lower fire rate, to ensure the player doesn't get overwhelmed but always feels on the edge of being overwhelmed). As it stands, enemies just don't feel dangerous, which is a horrible misplay for a game with such a solid core combat system. Having adjustable 'player damage taken' and maybe even adjustable 'enemy accuracy' would solve a lot of the core combat issues.

It's strange, it's fun, it's easy, it's enjoyable and a pleasant surprise for an Early Access game. It's exceptionally short, new, and enjoyable for what there is currently in the game. I'd at best call this currently a strong demo than a game.

From seeing how you interact with your ship's parts, the map, the NPCs. You will find those little animation quirks just like in Helldivers 2. The game's simple, very easy to grasp, you can feel the scale much like in No Mans Sky. The matches with other people feel inviting but railroaded and brief, much like doing anything in No Mans Sky or Call of Duty. There's moments you feel like you're in Deep Rock Galatic based on how you interact with things from your ship to grappling, polished and smooth. It's like Star Citizen in the sens of 3D mobility, moving on an X, Y, and Z plane can be extremely overwhelming and disorientating. I'm not sure why it is for me but that Z motion while moving X and or Y just never feels good, I can play VR for hours but the nano second I experience this on a monitor it's like being drunk instantly... Plenty of people love that feeling because it's more immersive, it's more engaging and realistic. I agree, I'll just be somewhere in the ship not helping with the dog fights.

The game I feel will have that endless replayability like Star Citizen and No Mans Sky, hopefully they decide to make every update free too, otherwise give us something like Helldivers 2 or Deep Rock Galatic. Time will tell.

More importantly... Do you like sci-fi? Do you like space dog fights? Do you enjoy good co-op games?

Initially, I was a bit put off by the similarities to Void Crew. I usually find it distasteful when mechanics are copied without any attempt by the developer to make them their own. Fortunately, there are enough unique elements here for me to forgive it. I will silently hope it's an homage.

The gameplay at higher difficulties is fast-paced and engaging. The game rewards you for ensuring you have crew members in the right places at the right time. During combat, surplus crew can leave the ship and board enemy corvettes rather than sinking huge amounts of ammo into them. However, if you send everyone out and your ship takes damage, the pilot alone is usually unable to bring it back from the brink. This creates a highly enjoyable tension.

Ground combat works similarly; you are often required to storm enemy encampments or facilities. This also rewards teamplay and coordinationâ€”specifically ensuring the team packs the right gear and stays close together to reduce the risk of enemy flanks, which can be devastating.

However, the fact that the game is in Early Access is very obvious. There are features missing all over the place, and there isn't enough content yet to keep it fun for long periods. Progressing in the story and unlocking new sections of the map feels grindy and unsatisfying.

Sadly I cannot recommend this game just yet. This game has a massive identity crisis and with current content it's essentially an extended demo.

First let me commend this game for what it does right:
- combat is fun and satisfying, both when flying the ship and when on foot, there's issues with it like scarse ammo, harder difficulties throwing obscene amounts of enemies at you from buggy spawn points and heavy weapons being a waste of inventory slots (more on inventory slots in a second) but overall it's a pleasant experience with strong potential.
- the current system of missions is quite varied with multiple random events, as you fly a lot of these missions it will need more than that but it's a good start
- concept of ship being damaged and needing repairs while not new is quite fun and feels well executed
- lore is good enough for a game of this type

Now with the negatives:
- The game struggles with identity regarding progression-based gameplay and rougelite approach. It asks you to sink in hours of gameplay for very little reward yet at the same time if you fail with your party - recovery will cost you dearly as weapons that you might have been collecting through 5-10 different missions simply disappear. Re-collecting them will take ages. Having both slow, incremental progression yet at the same time harsh punishments that can erase a whole day worth of progress feel like disrespect to player's time, especially since all missions depend only on the last stage, no matter how well you've done in prior stages. Pick one: either slow grindy progression with scaling difficulty and permanent progress, or fast non-permanent progression resetting every mission, with RNG based power upgrades that all disappear on failure.
- Inventory slots are picked straight from Lethal Company-like extraction games, limited to 4 of whatever, however 1 slot is already permanent so essentially only 3 are left for the player. Given small amounts of ammunition and large amounts of enemies you usually end up taking 2 weapons extra leaving only one slot for any loot, making it really cumbersome and frustrating to play around.
- There's currently very few quests in the game, they are also all very basic.
- Thereâ€™s an obvious opportunity for functional armor stats, but there's nothing there, it's just cosmetics. It feels like the devs intended to do more here but dropped it to push out Early Access.
- Rewards from mission stages are so wildly inconsistent that difficulty levels barely matter. If you get the right artifacts, Hard missions become trivial. If you get nothing useful, even Easy becomes annoying without good guns.

Thereâ€™s a good game buried in here, and the core mechanics have real promise. But right now the progression, inventory system, and lack of meaningful content hold it back badly. Iâ€™ll keep an eye on development, but I canâ€™t recommend it yet.

CONS!!! - You lose the vast majority of everything you collect after each mission.  You have 3 slots on your character to carry items. (technically 4 but one can not be changed).  EVERYTHING ELSE is deleted at the end of each mission.  You could have found some incredible weapons, tools, ship upgrades etc.  It doesn't matter, if you are not holding it in one of the 3 slots it is deleted at the end of the mission.

Some upgrades to your ship do carry over, but they must be installed components.  However the (artifacts) which are installed and can provide significant buffs to your ship, are also deleted at the end of every mission.

Along with deleting the vast majority of all your cool loot, they also delete any addition a ship / shield repair kits you may have stocked up on, as well as the currency "materia" which is used to create them.  So you have to start every single mission with NOTHING but the clothes on your back and about 1/2 the installed components on your ship.  You could technically but materia canisters to take into a mission and have them at the beginning, but that is prohibitively expensive.

Your shields do not auto recharge.  You actually have to build 4 components, exit the ship, do a space walk, and install these components on 4 different areas of the ship to recharge your shields.  Which is gone the first time a enemy gunship strafs your ship.  The method to repair the ship is similar but at least you dont have to leave the ship.  You build the components, which you can need up to 5 of to fully repair, and you have to stand in front of a console and insert them one at a time every 5 seconds or so.  IF you are playing solo, and piloting the ship in battle, then your robotic companion will build and use repair kits only when the ship is critically damaged (assuming you have meteria).  Your companion will not fully repair the ship and will never repair the shields.  So every time you have a small battle, you have to park the ship, get up, and go do choirs for 1 - 3 minutes before you dare get into another scrap.  This might happen 3 - 10 times during a single mission.  The game seems to be designed to require a crew of 4, where 1 is pilot, 2 gunners, and one is a base b'tch who has to spend what could be a fun game just running around constantly repairing the ship without even a view of the combat happening outside.

EVEN THEN... the ability to build ammo resupply for the ship, or any repair components is severely limited by the RNG of "materia".  Which you can think of like a 3d printer cartridge.  Enemy ship randomly and very scarcely drop materia when they explode.  Then to actually get it you need to fly over to it.  A collector outside your ship picks it up, but is apparently incapable of routing it into the ship to be used.  So you have to park, get out of your seat, do another space walk to collect two separate containers.  Bring them inside, and put them into a recycling bin to actually get to use the materia.  Good luck if you are in battle, out of shield and ammo, and just need a smidgen to build bullets to finish off the last enemy.  You are going to be a sitting duck for a while while you get this sorted.  The game always only lets enough materia drop to barely get you to the next area, assuming you did everything right, and quickly dispatch your enemies before they do to much damage.  Its incredibly irritating.  It kinda feels like you are a soldier sent out with 1 bullet, and the only way to progress is to use that to kill another soldier and take his bullets.  But he might have 1 - 3 bullets.  He will never have a full mag.  So irritating.

Then there are the scripted losses.  When you get to the end of some missions your AI companion say "lets get out of here" and enemy ship arrive.  Perhaps you got really lucky on the RNG and build up a small stockpile of materia, so you choose to fight off this fleet rather than warp away like a cowardly dog with its tail between its legs.  You want to feel like you actually won, instead of barely escaped.  NOPE.  The game is programed to make you lose if you do this.  The enemy ship NEVER drop materia, and they NEVER stop coming.  So no matter your skill you will run out of materia and die, if you don't warp out in the middle of the battle.  This seems to be a common theme of many of the missions which I find intolerable.  That's not winning, it just "not" loosing.

I strongly recommend against this game in its current condition.  At least some of these game mechanics should at least be optional, and some should be changed completely.

Sadly I cannot recommend this game just yet. This game has a massive identity crisis and with current content it's essentially an extended demo.

First let me commend this game for what it does right:
- combat is fun and satisfying, both when flying the ship and when on foot, there's issues with it like scarse ammo, harder difficulties throwing obscene amounts of enemies at you from buggy spawn points and heavy weapons being a waste of inventory slots (more on inventory slots in a second) but overall it's a pleasant experience with strong potential.
- the current system of missions is quite varied with multiple random events, as you fly a lot of these missions it will need more than that but it's a good start
- concept of ship being damaged and needing repairs while not new is quite fun and feels well executed
- lore is good enough for a game of this type

Now with the negatives:
- The game struggles with identity regarding progression-based gameplay and rougelite approach. It asks you to sink in hours of gameplay for very little reward yet at the same time if you fail with your party - recovery will cost you dearly as weapons that you might have been collecting through 5-10 different missions simply disappear. Re-collecting them will take ages. Having both slow, incremental progression yet at the same time harsh punishments that can erase a whole day worth of progress feel like disrespect to player's time, especially since all missions depend only on the last stage, no matter how well you've done in prior stages. Pick one: either slow grindy progression with scaling difficulty and permanent progress, or fast non-permanent progression resetting every mission, with RNG based power upgrades that all disappear on failure.
- Inventory slots are picked straight from Lethal Company-like extraction games, limited to 4 of whatever, however 1 slot is already permanent so essentially only 3 are left for the player. Given small amounts of ammunition and large amounts of enemies you usually end up taking 2 weapons extra leaving only one slot for any loot, making it really cumbersome and frustrating to play around.
- There's currently very few quests in the game, they are also all very basic.
- Thereâ€™s an obvious opportunity for functional armor stats, but there's nothing there, it's just cosmetics. It feels like the devs intended to do more here but dropped it to push out Early Access.
- Rewards from mission stages are so wildly inconsistent that difficulty levels barely matter. If you get the right artifacts, Hard missions become trivial. If you get nothing useful, even Easy becomes annoying without good guns.

Thereâ€™s a good game buried in here, and the core mechanics have real promise. But right now the progression, inventory system, and lack of meaningful content hold it back badly. Iâ€™ll keep an eye on development, but I canâ€™t recommend it yet.

At first I thought this game was going to be a perfect example of needing more time to cook, but after the 20 hours (including the demo) in the game I have, I feel very different now. 

First off I want to say, the Route Keepsake Games took with Jump Space is hands down one of the best for early access I have seen in a while, They really did nail down their gameplay loop making sure everything feels decent & works properly. However that biggest strength also ends up being their biggest weakness here as well, content. The amount of unique mission types / map layouts is very very sparse here, things start to feel repetitive pretty dang fast because you can tell they really wanted to make sure the core concept was working, If this was my only complaint I would gladly give the game a recommend and move on, however as my time with the game increased, I started realizing there are issues with this game that I don't know can be ironed out of the experience.

Lets get the most obvious offender out of the way here, the campaign. The story is downright just absolutely forgettable to the point of leaving me shocked how much time and effort is put into it both voice acting and unskippable dialogue as mission briefings before heading on a mission, however this issue is the easiest to fix as well, just make the mission briefings skippable and you are good to go.

My predominant issue lies both with ship combat / movement and The FPS combat / movement. They have this 5.5/10 feeling, where everything does work and come together but nothing about any of the combat or movement really feels fantastic or has that wow quality, it just works. Sometimes you got a zip line around to get stuff done but it feels very minimal with what you can do with it and not super exciting to use. Yes you can Space walk but besides   boarding ships (a very quick and dull affair), and collecting loot from scannable bonus areas, there is really no use for it. 

There isn't a unique element to this game that feels like it's giving the game an identity, It just feels like it is a bunch of different ideas thrown together and put into a aspect to this game, Don't get me wrong it's a slightly above average package but there's just nothing there to make me really feel like this game is offering me something I can't get somewhere else in some regard. 

Artstyle is going to vary greatly from person to person but for me the color palette, weapon design, and enemy design just feels so bland and uninspired, nothing really grabs my attention or comes across as cool or unique, it all is functional. The weapon upgrades only add a splash of color and some scopes to them usually, all the robot enemies feel like robots I could be fighting in another game with mechanical baddies. all of your armor outfits look like generic armor, all the ship weapons are your usual big space guns, ect.

To me it feels like they tried to make something that was too people pleasing in almost every way so it never really gets the chance to shine in any specific way at all everything just kind of sits together like a slightly above average casserole you're eating, is it food you don't have to choke down and will be able to eat without complaining? Sure! But is it a meal that you  ask for the recipe for so you can make it for all your family and friends? no. It simply is just functional in too many ways, sure there aren't many bugs, or glitches and everything you want from the core experience is there but everything around that core experience feels so....lifeless. In a way this game comes off just as mechanical and function bound as the robots you are killing in the game, If you are someone who just wants a fun game to shoot enemies that you can play with friends go for it, but the lack of having any personal identity or bringing anything unique to the table really just makes it a game I don't want to stay with at all. 

TLDR; Gameplay and core of the game works very well and not buggy at all for early access but the game doesn't have enough content, while also not having any unique gameplay elements or a gripping world or art style to keep people around for long, worth getting if you just want something to do while playing with friends, otherwise a forgettable experience that won't be able to be fixed by adding more features and content

This game almost nails it. I played the early demo version when it launched with my stack of friends, and we all felt the same way about it. Incredibly fun, but in need of some work. It's a real shame the devs didn't listen. There is a lot I want to say and add, but I have only so much text allowance for these reviews. I'll share what I can. 

What I need to point out, above all else, is that this game gives something nothing else quite manages. Seeing your ship, being on the deck during combat, and having the ability to walk out and onto the hull in the heat of battle, is just the coolest f**king thing ever. It creates gorgeous moments that leave you yearning for another run with your friends. A pilot weaving through debris while your friend guns down an enemy gunship the moment you step out to repair a materia leak is breathtaking. The way you can see everything happening around you gives that perfect sense of scale. You feel small on your ship, but far from insignificant. It's a feeling that no other game has given me, especially not with friends. Especially when you repair your ship enough to go boarding another vessel, take it down, then grapple right back home in time to fight another fire.

The good: 

Gameplay loop. With friends, this game's gameplay loop is incredibly fun. The ship itself gives access to a lot of silly things you can just mess around with to have fun. The emotes paired with chairs are a natural fit for friends wanting to just goof around. When you're not doing that, the mechanics of the combat are heady. The pilot is always a necessity, and I can't really imagine this game as a solo. Where this game truly shines is once you have more crew, allowing for the other mechanics to truly shine. 

Gunning from within the ship is pretty nice, if not entirely unique. It gets more engaging once you get mounted weapons, like railguns, to let you unleash some real devastation on your enemies. The real chaos begins when you take basically any ship damage, because things go wrong fast. Fires start up, radiation leaks, your ship's lifeblood (materia) can leak, and you need to do rapid repairs. The moment this happens, the casual combat gets frantic. But it's a good frantic, because it greatly rewards fast responses from your crew. I didn't expect to be the one running around putting out fires, shooting from the gunner seat, and managing ship health, but here I am. It's appealing and necessary. 

But the other half of space combat is just as alluring, and I absolutely cannot get enough of it. This game gives you a grapple hook. A grapple hook with simply absurd range. If it were any shorter, it would harm the game drastically. Any longer and I probably wouldn't stop using it. This game lets you board enemy ships to take them down, and take them down fast. Bigger ships take longer, and even BIGGER ships yield some real loot. It's an incredibly fun, fast paced mechanic that adds a whole new level to the already enjoyable space fights. There is simply no other game I've seen that lets you jump out of your ship to take down a corvette you can't shoot because your railguns are down. It is exhilarating. 

The bad:

Developers are questionably listening to feedback. 

This game has improved a lot, but also lost some things along the way. The game runs WAY worse than the demo. My 4090, even with DLSS on, is struggling to get 90 frames around enemies. My friend with a lesser card is often hitting 12fps. I'm not sure what happened, because the demo ran smooth. This is a huge issue that I hope gets addressed sooner rather than alter. 

Items not held are lost inbetween runs, automatically sold for salvage...even if you put them on a shelf. I don't like that items labeled as "Decorative" are deleted after runs, as they hold no salvage value. They're worth a little materia, but given their very titular nature, I expected them to remain as just that. Decorations you could keep. 

Shelves, in general, are a flawed system that could make for an amazing feature. They seem intended for you to prep exits with weapons and gear. I love that so much. The idea of having your ship- YOUR ship- stocked with items of your choosing and ready to use in the heat of battle is amazing. You memorize it so that you're prepped when things go bad. But that's not possible. Even items on shelves are deleted. Sold for scrap. Even if those items lose their value, let me hoard. Let me shove my ship so full of things that it bursts. I'm losing out on the value, so it's not exactly like I'm reaping the rewards anyways. I'd be plenty happy to see them have no value if kept like that, ensuring you don't stockpile for a big payout. I just want the ship to be MY ship. Also, there's a glitch where shelf items get stuck. Very bad glitch. 

Spiderbots still suck. They made quite literally no sound in the beta, meaning little flamethrowers would just sneak up on you and burn you to death. They...kind of make sound now? They make a sound on spawn, but it doesn't follow their body, leaving them still soundless until killed. Even their attack is soundless. My entire group confirmed this, so it's not just me. 

Your ship's name not appearing on the side simply will not do. It's the final touch lacking from making the vessel truly yours. I really hope that, eventually, we see that changed. 

Large space debris, like exploded vessels, have terrible hitboxes. The first time I got truly frustrated with the game was during a very high stakes mission in which I died because I couldn't fly through a hole large enough for my entire ship. Except, I wasn't in my ship. It was just me, the very small person utterly dwarfed by this hole. Hitboxes like this will outright kill you, and that's some simply bad design in a game where half your time is spent flying around as a very vulnerable human. 

Your flashlights suck. The areas you need to use it don't actually get naturally darker, but simply drop all lighting...so your flashlight also does nothing. It also just sucks in general, making it doubly lame. Using your jetpack shuts it off as well, so you have to flick it on and off a lot.

Mission diversity in the first zone is very lacking. Either we got really unlucky with spawns, or there are only three mission types, one of which is nearly identical to another. Complaints about diversity are well warranted, at least for zone one. I'm hoping other zones branch out, because if not, that's a huge problem.

Overall: 

I want to love this game. But I hate that the devs are being cheeky about feedback, and that its difficulty is artificial.

Not in any way that makes sense, just whenever the mission designer thought it was time for some shooting. And it's kinda half-ass, too. Like, there are big mech things but they just show up whenever. Not as a boss fight or something, just in the middle of waiting for several minutes for a door to open while you go around and pull levers to "override" the door opening system. Mysteriously, every door in the game either takes several people to open, running around to six places to pull levers, or some combination of the two. I get that it's early EA but come on, you couldn't think of anything more convincing? Like having me fix a gear or coolant line or something? Just buttons to shoot my science pistol at?

There are dozens of things so dumb that it totally kills all immersion. There is a zero percent chance that if this was actually a thing that happened, these people, this plot, etc, that things would behave the way they do in the game. It just gets dumber the more you think about it. Here are some examples: 

You can upgrade your ship, but you can't upgrade your carried guns, get armor or a better personal shield, or even use grenades. Guns do have upgrades, but you just have to randomly find them. You can bring weapons back to your militarized hangar/mission hub, but no one figured out that you can maybe put them in a box for later use. Because why would a resistance fighter need a gun? If you lose your gun in space, find another one, because the resistance lost all the ones you brought home last time.

You have a matter crafter on ship that can craft repair items and consumables, but not guns, of course. You're in a spaceship advanced enough to warp, but they haven't learned to make fire suppression systems yet. Your ship has shields, but when they lose their batteries, you replace them from OUTSIDE the ship, not inside. Why? So you can get shot at, of course. Why would they put that inside the ship?

Your ship will harvest materia from space, but it won't send it to the cargo bay--it puts it in a container, which you then have to move yourself. Your ship has scanners, but they only detect stuff scripted for the mission. IE, not any out-of-the-way loot. Mission loot shows up for some reason, tho.

The button to open airlock doors isn't on the airlock door, nor did anyone at Space Engineering School figure out how to make them work automatically. We reserve that advanced technology for grocery stores. The Dart ship only has a door on one side, just to add hassle. The main ship has a deliberately confusing layout, which might work if it was a pleasure vessel. It's not, though. It's a military craft but it doesn't really have duty stations people expect to stay in. There's the pilot, and then all the other players running around frantically doing everything else. The very important systems are spread throughout the ship and you're going to use 6 staircases getting anywhere. I'm convinced they did that on purpose to make it feel more 'tense' when you're in a bad spot.

Like, I love the idea of the game. It looks great, runs great, feels good to play. There are lots of cool ideas here and some of the roguelike advancement elements are interesting. I suspect they'll be doing a lot of tuning as they go, and I don't really regret buying it to play with friends. We had a good time for a few hours there. It's just that now the novelty is starting to wear off and so much of it feels fake, contrived, and forced, that I don't recommend it to anyone at this point. 

Happy to change my review after future updates. We'll see how it goes.

Let me preface this review by saying that I have found this game to be very fun (when it works). The gameplay loop is intense, fun and addictive, and the game is pretty well polished for an early access title. Sure there are some problems such as getting stuck inside terrain, or items disappearing when dropped, but these are fairly typical small problems that one would expect to see in an early access title, and they should get fixed.

The reason I am (with a heavy heart) giving this title the dreaded thumbs down is because it lacks a fundamental feature which it should have included right out of the box: A robust reconnect/resume system.

As it stands currently, if you are playing with a friend and the friend gets disconnected, they have to wait until you have finished the current node (map). They cannot reconnect until you jump to the next node. What makes this even worse is if they get disconnected during the final node, they cannot reconnect at all, and they gain NO REWARD.

This is a pretty big deal, since some runs can easily take 1 hour or longer. To invest that amount of time into a run to walk away empty-handed is absolutely not acceptable. It is a serious level of disrespect and disregard for the player's time and effort.

It would be unacceptable even if my internet connection were bad, but it's made even worse by the fact there clearly are wide spread connection/stability issues with the game, judging by the number of complaints one can see on Discord. Ultimately it doesn't matter whether it's the game, or Epic online services, or the player's dial up internet connection - ALL of these problems are solved effectively by a robust resume system.

Browsing through the feature requests channel/threads in Discord, there is some indication that the devs are "aware of the problem" and "want to improve it", but I have to wonder - If you have designed a game where a single session can take 1+ hour, how is it that a robust "resume" system hasn't already been built in from the very beginning? Why is it being discussed for improvement like an afterthought? What possible justification could exist for that?

Worse yet, there is a developer comment acknowledging this issue from over 3 months ago, and yet the resume system is still awful to this day. It definitely seems like improving it is not a priority for them.

It concerns me, because it tells me that: 

1) The devs didn't think their systems out very well from a point of practicality and user friendliness.
 
2) The devs do not respect the player's time and effort enough to make these factors a core consideration in the design of their game.

I will gladly change my review and start recommending this game if/when the developers have implemented a robust resume system that doesn't rob the player of their rewards or time (make them wait 20+ minutes to rejoin their friends).

Devs, if you are reading this: I really think you're onto a winner gameplay wise, but if you truly want your game to shine, you need to make respect for your players a core part of your design philosophy, not an afterthought. Like many people, my leisure time is limited. I want to spend it on games that respect me, not games that take away my shinies and say "too bad, so sad".

"The Good"
The gameplay loop is really fun. Jump in, fight ships, repair your ship, board ships to loot them, board ground stations to do objectives, etc. This all works really well.

"The Bad"
There are lots of clipping issues. Enemy space ships will fly through debris that you can't. Enemy ground units will board your ship and then get stuck in the walls. Ground combat can be chaotic when enemies spawn outside the map and start shooting you. There isn't a great progression system either. You don't keep loot, only the weapons you had on you. There needs to be some sort of "stash" or "locker" system in the hanger.

"The Ugly"
Join in progress makes you wait until the team jumps, which is really annoying. You don't get to spectate either, you just sit at a loading screen. The AI placeholder voice acting is somehow worse than normal text to speech programs, they fall right into the uncanny valley. The cinematics are slow to progress slideshows, they need to be sped up or shortened. The writing feels like it might be AI generated as well.

The short of it is: boring, simplistic and too buggy. There in some promise here, but wait for patches.

Mushy, generic co-op FPS gameplay loop where you magdump peashooters into boxy robots with no noticeable feedback until they arbitrarily drop dead. Imagine early Warframe, except without any of the fun movement, and also you're using the deeply unsatisfying guns from No Man's Sky.

Space combat similarly feels underbaked, with the nose of the ship whipping around wildly at the slightest movement, rather than having any sort of weight or momentum behind it. Enemy missiles sluggishly chug along as if through gelatin, allowing you to literally dip the nose of your ship to avoid them. This bizarre lack of momentum is especially jarring when viewed from outside the ship, where you can see it spinning in place at absurd speeds as the pilot moves their mouse around; no thrusters, no animations, nothing.

You'll be seeing this quite a lot, too, as despite the ship... existing, it mostly just serves as a way to ferry you from one dull co-op shooting segment to another. The game's entire loop consists of flying to a point of interest, disembarking, shooting a few enemies, then carrying some loot back to the ship. Most often this means a wave survival mission that involves pressing a co-op button every 5-10 seconds over the course of several minutes. It's like the drill from Payday, only worse, because it breaks down every few seconds instead of every minute or so. I want to emphasize that I am [i]not exaggerating,[/i] it's legitimately every 10 seconds or so.

To add insult to injury, the game aggressively tutorializes you, locking you out of seemingly the only roguelike element (Artifacts), as well as the basic functionality of your ship, until you've completed several easy (and tediously long) missions. If you're unlucky, the map may not even give you access to the correct mission type to complete these story quests, forcing you to play even more long, easy missions with the gimped tutorial ship until they decide to appear.

Oh yeah, and all those currencies you're collecting, about those... bet you're wondering when you unlock the ability to spend them, huh? Welp, too bad, because the shopkeeper isn't implemented yet and there's nothing to do with them, lol. Right, and that other ship that you can unlock? It's got crippling design flaws that prevent in-flight repairs, and the developers have acknowledged that they'll have to revisit it and redesign it, so it might as well not exist.

I get why people are hyped, the core concepts here are interesting, but the execution leaves much to be desired, and the game's aesthetics are about as bland as vanilla yogurt. Worse, this feels more like a proof of concept than a project that just needs a bit more development time, and even then, I'm not sure there's really any [i]vision[/i] behind this project; most everything here is taken directly from existing games, albeit executed poorly. Right now it feels like this game has no voice, no identity, if that makes any sense.

[b]Hard not recommended.[/b] Severely underbaked. I'd suggest you wait for [i]considerable[/i] developments to the gameplay loop before giving it a look, as what's here is barely a demo, and not a particularly interesting one, at that.

CONS!!! - You lose the vast majority of everything you collect after each mission.  You have 3 slots on your character to carry items. (technically 4 but one can not be changed).  EVERYTHING ELSE is deleted at the end of each mission.  You could have found some incredible weapons, tools, ship upgrades etc.  It doesn't matter, if you are not holding it in one of the 3 slots it is deleted at the end of the mission.

Some upgrades to your ship do carry over, but they must be installed components.  However the (artifacts) which are installed and can provide significant buffs to your ship, are also deleted at the end of every mission.

Along with deleting the vast majority of all your cool loot, they also delete any addition a ship / shield repair kits you may have stocked up on, as well as the currency "materia" which is used to create them.  So you have to start every single mission with NOTHING but the clothes on your back and about 1/2 the installed components on your ship.  You could technically but materia canisters to take into a mission and have them at the beginning, but that is prohibitively expensive.

Your shields do not auto recharge.  You actually have to build 4 components, exit the ship, do a space walk, and install these components on 4 different areas of the ship to recharge your shields.  Which is gone the first time a enemy gunship strafs your ship.  The method to repair the ship is similar but at least you dont have to leave the ship.  You build the components, which you can need up to 5 of to fully repair, and you have to stand in front of a console and insert them one at a time every 5 seconds or so.  IF you are playing solo, and piloting the ship in battle, then your robotic companion will build and use repair kits only when the ship is critically damaged (assuming you have meteria).  Your companion will not fully repair the ship and will never repair the shields.  So every time you have a small battle, you have to park the ship, get up, and go do choirs for 1 - 3 minutes before you dare get into another scrap.  This might happen 3 - 10 times during a single mission.  The game seems to be designed to require a crew of 4, where 1 is pilot, 2 gunners, and one is a base b'tch who has to spend what could be a fun game just running around constantly repairing the ship without even a view of the combat happening outside.

EVEN THEN... the ability to build ammo resupply for the ship, or any repair components is severely limited by the RNG of "materia".  Which you can think of like a 3d printer cartridge.  Enemy ship randomly and very scarcely drop materia when they explode.  Then to actually get it you need to fly over to it.  A collector outside your ship picks it up, but is apparently incapable of routing it into the ship to be used.  So you have to park, get out of your seat, do another space walk to collect two separate containers.  Bring them inside, and put them into a recycling bin to actually get to use the materia.  Good luck if you are in battle, out of shield and ammo, and just need a smidgen to build bullets to finish off the last enemy.  You are going to be a sitting duck for a while while you get this sorted.  The game always only lets enough materia drop to barely get you to the next area, assuming you did everything right, and quickly dispatch your enemies before they do to much damage.  Its incredibly irritating.  It kinda feels like you are a soldier sent out with 1 bullet, and the only way to progress is to use that to kill another soldier and take his bullets.  But he might have 1 - 3 bullets.  He will never have a full mag.  So irritating.

Then there are the scripted losses.  When you get to the end of some missions your AI companion say "lets get out of here" and enemy ship arrive.  Perhaps you got really lucky on the RNG and build up a small stockpile of materia, so you choose to fight off this fleet rather than warp away like a cowardly dog with its tail between its legs.  You want to feel like you actually won, instead of barely escaped.  NOPE.  The game is programed to make you lose if you do this.  The enemy ship NEVER drop materia, and they NEVER stop coming.  So no matter your skill you will run out of materia and die, if you don't warp out in the middle of the battle.  This seems to be a common theme of many of the missions which I find intolerable.  That's not winning, it just "not" loosing.

I strongly recommend against this game in its current condition.  At least some of these game mechanics should at least be optional, and some should be changed completely.
